key_points: Relief is on the way for Texas with temperatures expected to reach the 60s and 70s after a devastating week of winter storms.
At least 26 people have died as a result of the storms since February 11.
Millions lost power, faced food and water shortages, and experienced burst pipes and other cold-related damages.
Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo warned Texans as the historic storm approached, highlighting the severe weather's onset.
Rolling blackouts began early in the week due to "record-breaking electric demand," according to ERCOT.
More than four million customers were without power at the peak of the outages, prompting critiques of ERCOT's preparedness and response.
Carbon monoxide poisoning claimed several lives due to unsafe heating methods during the power outage.
Water disruptions and boil-water notices were widespread, affecting nearly half of the state's population by the end of the week.
Gov. Abbott called for an investigation into ERCOT, as the power grid operator defended its decisions to prevent a total system collapse.
Food supply issues arose, compounding the crisis, as millions of Texans struggled with power outages and a lack of basic necessities.
spokespersons: Toby Baker (Executive Director, Texas Commission on Environmental Quality)
Marc Bloom (President and CEO, Houston Methodist)
